1168696_13_ITEM15_P19_S0	The undersigned, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer of Regal Entertainment Group, a Delaware corporation (the "Company"), each hereby certifies that, to his/her knowledge on the date hereof:
1168696_13_ITEM15_P20_S0	a. the Form 10-K of the Company for the fiscal year ended December 27, 2012 , filed on the date hereof with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "Report") fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and b. the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P0_S0	Regal Entertainment Group, a Delaware corporation organized on March 6, 2002 ("we," "us," "our," the "Company" or "Regal"), is the parent company of Regal Entertainment Holdings, Inc. ("REH"), which is the parent company of Regal Cinemas Corporation ("Regal Cinemas") and its subsidiaries.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P0_S1	Regal Cinemas' subsidiaries include Regal Cinemas, Inc. ("RCI") and its subsidiaries, which include Edwards Theatres, Inc. ("Edwards"), Regal CineMedia Corporation ("RCM") and United Artists Theatre Company ("United Artists").
1168696_14_ITEM1_P0_S2	The terms Regal or the Company, REH, Regal Cinemas, RCI, Edwards, RCM and United Artists shall be deemed to include the respective subsidiaries of such entities when used in discussions included herein regarding the current operations or assets of such entities.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our Internet address is www.regmovies.com .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P1_S1	Our annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K, and any amendments to these reports, are available free of charge on our Internet website under the heading "Investor Relations" as soon as reasonably practicable after we electronically file such material with, or furnish it to, the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "Commission").
1168696_14_ITEM1_P1_S2	The contents of our Internet website are not incorporated into this report.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Company manages its business under one reportable segment: theatre exhibition operations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P2_S1	DESCRIPTION OF BUSINESS Overview We operate the largest and most geographically diverse theatre circuit in the United States, consisting of 7,394 screens in 580 theatres in 42 states along with Guam, Saipan, American Samoa and the District of Columbia as of December 26, 2013 , with approximately 229 million attendees for the fiscal year ended December 26, 2013 ("fiscal 2013 ").
1168696_14_ITEM1_P2_S2	Our geographically diverse circuit includes theatres in 46 of the top 50 U.S. designated market areas.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P2_S3	We operate multi-screen theatres and, as of December 26, 2013 , had an average of 12.7 screens per location, which is well above the North American motion picture exhibition industry average.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P2_S4	We develop, acquire and operate multi-screen theatres primarily in mid-sized metropolitan markets and suburban growth areas of larger metropolitan markets throughout the United States.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Company's fiscal year ends on the first Thursday after December 25, which in certain years (such as fiscal 2014) results in a 53-week fiscal year.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P3_S1	For fiscal 2013 , we reported total revenues, income from operations and net income attributable to controlling interest of $3,038.1 million , $339.8 million and $157.7 million , respectively.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P3_S2	In addition, we generated $346.9 million of cash flows from operating activities during fiscal 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P3_S3	Our business strategy focuses on enhancing our position in the motion picture exhibition industry by distributing value to our stockholders, realizing selective growth opportunities through new theatre construction, managing, expanding and upgrading our existing asset base with new technologies and customer amenities and capitalizing on prudent industry consolidation and partnership opportunities.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P3_S4	This strategy should enable us to continue to produce the free cash flow necessary to maintain a prudent allocation of our capital among dividend payments, debt service and repayment and investment in our theatre assets, all to provide meaningful value to our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	Key elements of our business strategy include: Maximizing Stockholder Value.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P4_S1	We believe that our cash dividends are an efficient means of distributing value to our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P4_S2	From our initial public offering ("IPO") in May 2002 through December 26, 2013 , we have returned approximately $3.7 billion to our stockholders in the form of cash dividends.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	Pursuing Selective Growth Opportunities and Active Asset Management.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P5_S1	We intend to selectively pursue expansion opportunities through new theatre construction that meet our strategic and financial return criteria.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P5_S2	We also intend to enhance our theatre operations by selectively expanding and upgrading existing properties in prime locations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	existing theatres and closing 11 underperforming theatres with 101 screens, ending the year with 580 theatres and 7,394 screens.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	We intend to continue to embrace innovative concepts that generate incremental revenue and cash flows for the Company and deliver a premium movie-going experience for our customers on three complementary fronts:
1168696_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	First, we believe the installation of premium screens allows us to offer our patrons all-digital large format experiences that generate incremental revenue and cash flows for the Company.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P8_S1	During fiscal 2013, we continued to install additional IMAX digital projection systems and RPX SM screens in select theatre locations across the U.S.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P8_S2	As of December 26, 2013 , our IMAX footprint consisted of a total of 82 IMAX screens and we operated a total of 62 RPX SM screens.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P8_S3	We have been encouraged by the operating results of our IMAX and RPX SM screens and to that end, we intend to install additional IMAX digital projection systems and RPX SM screens during fiscal 2014 and beyond.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P8_S4	In addition, during fiscal 2013, we began a new initiative to install luxury reclining seating at select locations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P8_S5	Based on promising initial results, we expect to offer luxury seating in approximately 20 to 25 locations by the end of fiscal 2014.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	Second, we believe that the enhancement of our food and beverage offerings has had a positive effect on our operating results and we expect to continue to invest in such food and beverage offerings in our theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P10_S0	To continually address consumer trends and customer preferences, we have focused on enlarging our menu of food and beverage products.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P10_S1	We have already expanded our menu to include hot made-to-order meals, customizable coffee, beer and wine and other specialty products in select theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P10_S2	During fiscal 2013, we offered an expanded menu of food items in 81 theatres and expect to offer these food items in approximately 75-90 additional theatres during fiscal 2014.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P10_S3	In addition, as of December 26, 2013 , we have successfully launched seven Cinebarre locations which offer patrons the convenience of a variety of lunch and dinner menu options, including beer and wine, served at the customer's seat before and during the featured film.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P11_S0	Third, we intend to continue our focus on interactive marketing programs aimed at increasing attendance and enhancing the overall customer experience.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P11_S1	We maintain a frequent moviegoer loyalty program, named the Regal Crown Club , to actively engage our core customers.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P11_S2	Regal Crown Club members are eligible for specified awards, such as concession items, based on purchases made at our participating theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P11_S3	As of December 26, 2013 , we had over nine million active members in the Regal Crown Club , making it the largest loyalty program in our industry, and these members accounted for approximately $921 million of the Company's box office and concession revenues during fiscal 2013.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P11_S4	In addition, we seek to develop patron loyalty through a number of other marketing programs such as summer children's film series, cross-promotional ticket redemptions and promotions within local communities.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S0	During 2012, we launched a mobile ticketing application designed to give customers quick access to box office information via their Apple iPhone or Android phone.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S1	The application provides customers the ability to find films, movie information, showtimes and special offers from Regal and purchase tickets for local theatres, thereby expediting the admissions process.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S2	Additionally, the application helps customers stay up-to-date on the latest coupons and Regal Crown Club loyalty program promotions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S3	This mobile application has been downloaded approximately 1.8 million times since its launch.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S4	We believe the product-driven success of our IMAX screens and growing portfolio of RPX SM screens and improved customer amenities such as luxury seating, coupled with the continued rollout of our expanded concession menu and widespread availability of mobile ticketing and other marketing initiatives allow us to deliver a premium experience in a majority of our key markets.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S5	We believe that our acquisition experience and capital structure position us well to take advantage of future acquisition opportunities and to participate in various partnership initiatives.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S6	We intend to selectively pursue accretive theatre acquisitions and theatre-related investments that enhance and more fully utilize our asset base to improve our consolidated operating results and free cash flow.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S7	For example, on March 29, 2013, we completed the acquisition of Hollywood Theaters, whereby we acquired a total of 43 theatres with 513 screens for an aggregate net cash purchase price of $194.4 million .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S8	The acquisition of Hollywood Theaters enhanced the Company s presence in 16 states and 3 U.S. territories.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S9	During November of 2012, we completed the acquisition of Great Escape Theatres in which we acquired a total of 25 theatres representing 301 screens for an aggregate net cash purchase price of approximately $90.0 million.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S10	The acquisition of the Great Escape Theatres circuit enhanced our presence in Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Missouri, Nebraska, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee and West Virginia.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S11	The 814 screens from Great Escape Theatres and Hollywood Theaters accounted for 16.3 million attendees, or 7.1% of total attendance for fiscal 2013, and contributed approximately $128.6 million , or 6.2% , of fiscal 2013 total admissions revenues.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P12_S12	See Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K for further discussion of these acquisitions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P13_S0	With respect to partnership initiatives, we maintain an investment in National CineMedia, LLC ("National CineMedia" or "NCM").
1168696_14_ITEM1_P14_S0	National CineMedia operates the largest digital in-theatre advertising network in North America representing approximately 19,900 U.S. theatres screens (of which approximately 19,100 are part of National CineMedia's digital content network) as of December 26, 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P14_S1	During 2013, approximately 710 million patrons attended movies shown in theatres in which National CineMedia currently has exclusive cinema advertising agreements in place.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P15_S0	National CineMedia concentrates on in-theatre advertising for its theatrical exhibition partners, which includes us, AMC Entertainment, Inc. ("AMC"), and Cinemark, Inc. ("Cinemark").
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S0	We believe our investment in National CineMedia generates incremental value for our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S1	See "National CineMedia Joint Venture" under Part I, Item I of this Form 10-K for further discussion of National CineMedia.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S2	We also maintain an investment in Open Road Films, a film distribution company jointly owned by us and AMC.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S3	Open Road Films was created to fill a gap in the marketplace created by the major studios big-budget franchise film strategy by marketing smaller budget films in a cost-effective manner which we believe will drive additional patrons to our theatres and generate a return on our capital investment.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S4	Open Road Films distributed seven films during 2013 which generated national box office revenues of approximately $148.0 million , and intends to distribute approximately six to eight films per year.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S5	As of December 26, 2013 , our cumulative cash investment in Open Road Films totaled $20.0 million.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S6	We believe our investment in Open Road Films will generate incremental value for our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P16_S7	In summary, we believe our business strategy should enable us to continue to produce the free cash flow necessary to maintain a prudent allocation of our capital among dividend payments, debt service and repayment and investment in our theatres assets, all to provide meaningful value to our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P17_S0	Competitive Strengths We believe that the following competitive strengths position us to capitalize on future opportunities: Industry Leader.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S0	We are the largest domestic motion picture exhibitor operating 7,394 screens in 580 theatres in 42 states along with Guam, Saipan, American Samoa and the District of Columbia.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S1	We believe that the quality and size of our theatre circuit is a significant competitive advantage for negotiating attractive national contracts and generating economies of scale.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S2	We believe that our market leadership allows us to capitalize on favorable attendance trends and attractive consolidation and partnership opportunities.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S3	Superior Management Drives Strong Operating Margins.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S4	Our operating philosophy focuses on efficient operations and strict cost controls at both the corporate and theatre levels.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S5	At the corporate level, we are able to capitalize on our size and operational expertise to achieve economies of scale in purchasing and marketing functions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P18_S6	We have developed an efficient purchasing and distribution supply chain that generates favorable concession margins.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P19_S0	At the theatre level, management devotes significant attention to cost controls through the use of financial data analysis, detailed management reports and performance-based compensation programs to encourage theatre managers to deliver a premium customer experience while effectively controlling costs and maximizing free cash flow.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S0	We have significant experience identifying, completing and integrating acquisitions of theatre circuits.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S1	Since our 2002 IPO, we have demonstrated our ability to enhance revenues and realize operating efficiencies through the successful acquisition and integration of nine theatre circuits, consisting of 225 theatres and 2,622 screens, including the recent acquisition of Hollywood Theaters in fiscal 2013.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S2	We have generally achieved immediate cost savings at acquired theatres and improved their profitability through the application of our consolidated operating functions and key supplier contracts.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S3	We believe that we operate one of the most modern theatre circuits among major motion picture exhibitors.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S4	As of December 26, 2013 , approximately 77% of our locations featured stadium seating and approximately 78% of our theatres had 10 or more screens.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S5	Our theatres have an average of 12.7 screens per location, which is well above the North American motion picture exhibition industry average.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P20_S6	We believe that our modern theatre portfolio coupled with our operating margins should allow us to generate significant cash flows from operations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P21_S0	Dividend Policy We believe that paying dividends on our shares of common stock is important to our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P21_S1	To that end, during fiscal 2013 , we paid to our stockholders four quarterly cash dividends of $0.21 per share on each outstanding share of our Class A and Class B common stock, or approximately $132.2 million in the aggregate.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P21_S2	Further, on February 13, 2014 , we declared a cash dividend of $0.22 per share on each outstanding share of Class A and Class B common stock.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P21_S3	The dividend is payable on March 14, 2014 to our stockholders of record on March 4, 2014 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P21_S4	This dividend reflects a $0.01 per share increase from the Company's last quarterly cash dividend of $0.21 per share declared on October 24, 2013.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P21_S5	These dividends have been or will be funded through cash flow from operations and available cash on hand.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P22_S0	and subject to applicable law, anticipate paying regular quarterly dividends on our Class A and Class B common stock for the foreseeable future.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P22_S1	The amount, if any, of the dividends to be paid in the future will depend upon our then available cash, anticipated cash needs, overall financial condition, loan agreement restrictions, future prospects for earnings and cash flows, as well as other relevant factors.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P22_S2	Dividends are considered quarterly and may be paid only when, and in such amounts as, approved by our board of directors.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P23_S0	The domestic motion picture exhibition industry is a mature business that has historically maintained steady long-term growth in revenues and attendance.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P23_S1	Since 1965, total box office revenues have grown at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 5% with annual attendance of approximately 1.3 billion attendees in 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P23_S2	Against this background of steady long-term growth in revenues and attendance, the exhibition industry has experienced periodic short-term increases and decreases in attendance and in turn box office revenues.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P23_S3	Consequently, we expect the cyclical nature of the domestic motion picture exhibition industry to continue for the foreseeable future.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P23_S4	However, we believe that long-term trends in motion picture attendance in the U.S. will continue to benefit the domestic motion picture exhibition industry.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P23_S5	For example, even during the most recent recessionary period, attendance levels remained stable.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P24_S0	Through the years, the domestic motion picture exhibition industry has experienced increased competition from other methods of delivering content to consumers, including network and syndicated television, cable and satellite television services, in-home video and DVD and pay-per-view services such as video on demand, digital downloads and streaming via the Internet.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P25_S0	Traditionally, when motion picture distributors license their films to the domestic exhibition industry, they refrain from licensing their products to other delivery channels for a period of time, commonly called the theatrical release window.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P25_S1	Over the past several years, the average period between a film's theatrical release and its in-home video or DVD release has remained relatively stable.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P25_S2	However, we believe that a material contraction of the theatrical release window could significantly dilute the consumer appeal of the out-of-home motion picture offering.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P25_S3	As a result, we continue to monitor the status of the theatrical release window during our film licensing decisions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P25_S4	Fundamentally, we believe that movie-going is a convenient, affordable and attractively priced form of out-of-home entertainment, which, on an average price per patron basis, continues to compare favorably to other out-of-home entertainment alternatives, such as concerts and sporting events.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S0	More recently, the domestic motion picture industry has largely converted from film-based media to electronic-based media, including the distribution of feature films in a digital format rather than a 35 mm film format.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S1	Virtually all entertainment content today can be exhibited digitally.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S2	Digital projection produces a consistent state-of-the-art presentation for patrons as there is no degradation of image over the exhibition period of the motion picture.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S3	We believe that operating a digital theatre circuit provides greater flexibility in scheduling our programming content, which has enhanced our capacity utilization, and enables us to generate incremental revenue from differentiated motion picture formats, such as digital 3D, and the exhibition of specialty content offerings through certain industry joint venture arrangements, such as AC JV, LLC and Open Road Films.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S4	Finally, the domestic motion picture exhibition industry is in the process of experimenting with various initiatives and concepts aimed at delivering a premium movie-going experience for its customers in order to differentiate services and build brand loyalty, which we believe will provide us the opportunity for incremental revenue and cash flows.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S5	We believe the benefits associated with delivering premium movie-going experiences are significant for our industry and provide us with the opportunity for incremental revenue from premium motion picture formats such as IMAX and our proprietary large screen format, RPX SM .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S6	Other initiatives include broadening food and beverage offerings along with food and beverage self-serve stations, in-theatre dining and bar service, the enhancement of loyalty programs and other customer engagement initiatives such as mobile ticketing applications, internet ticketing, social media and other marketing initiatives.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S7	Finally, motion picture exhibitors have begun to offer various other customer amenities including reserved seating and luxury reclining seating.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P26_S8	We are optimistic that these and other recent industry initiatives and trends will drive continued growth and strength for the domestic motion picture industry.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P27_S0	THEATRE OPERATIONS We operate the largest theatre circuit in the United States with 7,394 screens in 580 theatres in 42 states along with Guam, Saipan, American Samoa and the District of Columbia as of December 26, 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P27_S1	We operate theatres in 46 of the top 50 U.S. designated market areas, which include locations in suburban growth areas.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P27_S2	We target prime locations with excellent access to large, high patron-traffic areas.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P27_S3	We operate our theatre circuit using our Regal Cinemas, United Artists, Edwards, Great Escape Theatres and Hollywood Theaters brands through our wholly owned subsidiaries.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P27_S4	Our multi-screen theatre complexes typically contain 10 to 18 screens, each with auditoriums ranging from 100 to 500 seats.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P27_S5	As a result, our theatres appeal to a diverse group of patrons because we offer a wide selection of films and convenient show times.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S0	plush stadium seating with cup holders and retractable armrests and enhanced interiors featuring video game and party room areas adjacent to the theatre lobby.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S1	In addition, we have recently begun a new initiative to install luxury reclining seating at select locations in certain of our key markets.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S2	Our modern, multi-screen theatres are designed to increase profitability by optimizing revenues per square foot while reducing our operational costs on a per attendee basis.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S3	We vary auditorium seating capacities within the same theatre, allowing us to exhibit films on a more cost effective basis for a longer period of time by shifting films to smaller auditoriums to meet changing attendance levels.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S4	In addition, we realize significant operating efficiencies by having common box office, concessions, projection, lobby and restroom facilities, which enables us to spread some of our costs, such as payroll, advertising, rent and utility costs over a higher revenue base.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S5	We strategically schedule movie show times to reduce staffing requirements and box office and concession line congestion and to provide more desirable parking and traffic flow patterns.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S6	We also actively monitor ticket sales in order to quickly recognize demand surges, which enables us to add seating capacity quickly and efficiently.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P28_S7	In addition, we offer various forms of convenient ticketing methods, including print-at-home technology, self-serve kiosks, e-gift cards and mobile ticketing.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P29_S0	We believe that operating a theatre circuit consisting primarily of modern theatres enhances our ability to attract patrons and believe theatres larger than the current 10 to 18 screen megaplex are not able to generate attractive returns in most locations because of the substantial market suitability requirements to generate a level of profitability similar to the current megaplex format.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P29_S1	We also believe that another evolution of theatre formats beyond the current megaplex is unlikely to occur in the foreseeable future.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P29_S2	The following table details the number of locations and theatre screens in our theatre circuit ranked by the number of screens in each state along with Guam, Saipan, American Samoa and the District of Columbia as of December 26, 2013 :
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S0	theatres, divisional management and corporate management.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S1	We use these management reports and communications to closely monitor admissions and concessions revenues as well as accounting, payroll and workforce information necessary to manage our theatre operations effectively and efficiently.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S2	We seek experienced theatre managers and require new theatre managers to complete a comprehensive training program within the theatres and at the "Regal Entertainment University," which is held at our corporate office.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S3	The program is designed to encompass all phases of theatre operations, including our operating philosophy, policies, procedures and standards.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S4	In addition, we have an incentive compensation program for theatre-level management that rewards theatre managers for controlling operating expenses while complying with our operating standards.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S5	In addition, we have implemented quality assurance programs in all of our theatres to maintain clean, comfortable and modern facilities and monitor food service.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S6	To maintain quality and consistency within our theatre circuit, district and regional managers and various contractual service partners regularly inspect each theatre and provide recurring feedback.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S7	In addition, we consistently solicit feedback from our patrons through an on-line guest experience program whereby our guests rank and provide detailed comments and experiences for each of our theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P30_S8	Finally, we also conduct a "mystery shopper" program, which involves unannounced visits by unidentified customers who report on the quality of service, film presentation and cleanliness at individual theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P31_S0	NATIONAL CINEMEDIA JOINT VENTURE We maintain an investment in National CineMedia, which operates the largest digital in-theatre advertising network in North America representing approximately 19,900 U.S. theatres screens (of which approximately 19,100 are part of National CineMedia's digital content network) as of December 26, 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P31_S1	During 2013, approximately 710 million patrons attended movies shown in theatres in which National CineMedia currently has exclusive cinema advertising agreements in place.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P32_S0	National CineMedia concentrates on in-theatre advertising for its theatrical exhibition partners, which includes us, AMC and Cinemark.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P33_S0	As described further in Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K, on February 13, 2007, National CineMedia, Inc. ("NCM, Inc."), which serves as the sole manager of National CineMedia, completed an IPO of its common stock.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P33_S1	In connection with the IPO of NCM, Inc., RCM, through its wholly owned subsidiary Regal CineMedia Holdings, LLC ("RCH"), AMC and Cinemark amended and restated the operating agreement of National CineMedia and other ancillary agreements.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P33_S2	As a result of these agreements, we receive theatre access fees and mandatory distributions of excess cash from National CineMedia.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P33_S3	Subsequent to the IPO of NCM, Inc. and through December 26, 2013 , the Company received from National CineMedia approximately 10.8 million newly issued common units of National CineMedia as a result of the adjustment provisions of the Common Unit Adjustment Agreement, including approximately 3.4 million newly issued common units of National CineMedia during fiscal 2013 in connection with our acquisition of Hollywood Theaters.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P33_S4	These transactions, partially offset by the redemption of approximately 6.6 million of our National CineMedia common units for a like number of shares of NCM, Inc. common stock, which we sold in underwritten public offerings during fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2013, caused a net increase in the Company's ownership share in National CineMedia to 25.4 million common units.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P33_S5	As a result, on a fully diluted basis, we own a 20.0% interest in NCM, Inc. as of December 26, 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P34_S0	On December 26, 2013, National CineMedia sold its "Fathom Events" business to AC JV, LLC ( AC JV ), a newly-formed Delaware limited liability company owned, directly and indirectly, 32% by each of RCI, AMC and Cinemark and 4% by National CineMedia.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P35_S0	The Fathom Events business focuses on the marketing and distribution of live and pre-recorded entertainment programming to various theatre operators (including us, AMC and Cinemark) to provide additional programs to augment their feature film schedule and includes events such as live and pre-recorded concerts, opera and symphony, DVD product releases and marketing events, theatrical premieres, Broadway plays, live sporting events and other special events.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P36_S0	In consideration for the sale, National CineMedia received a total of $25 million in promissory notes from RCI, Cinemark and AMC (one-third or approximately $8.33 million from each).
1168696_14_ITEM1_P36_S1	The notes bear interest at 5.0% per annum.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P36_S2	Interest and principal payments are due annually in six equal installments commencing on the first anniversary of the closing.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P36_S3	In connection with the sale, National CineMedia entered into a transition services agreement to provide certain corporate overhead services for a fee and reimbursement for certain facilities services, creative services, technical event services, event management services and other specified costs to the new entity for a period of nine months following the closing.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P37_S0	Due to the related party nature of the transaction, National CineMedia formed a committee of independent directors that hired an investment banking firm who advised the committee and rendered an opinion as to the fairness of the transaction.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P38_S0	Since the Company does not have a controlling financial interest in AC JV, it accounts for its investment in AC JV under the equity method of accounting.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P38_S1	In addition, on December 26, 2013, RCI amended and restated its existing exhibitor service agreement with National CineMedia in connection with the sale by National CineMedia of its Fathom Events business.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P38_S2	AMC and Cinemark also amended and restated their respective existing exhibitor service agreements with National CineMedia in connection with the sale.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P38_S3	The existing exhibitor service agreements were modified to remove those provisions addressing the rights and obligations related to digital programing services of the Fathom Events business.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P39_S0	Restated Digital Programming Exhibitor Services Agreements that were entered into on December 26, 2013 by National CineMedia and each of RCI, AMC and Cinemark, respectively.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P39_S1	These Amended and Restated Digital Programming Exhibitor Services Agreements were then assigned by National CineMedia to AC JV as part of the sale.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P39_S2	See Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K for further discussion of National CineMedia and related transactions, including AC JV.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P40_S0	We maintain an investment in Digital Cinema Implementation Partners, LLC ("DCIP"), a joint venture company formed by Regal, AMC and Cinemark.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P40_S1	During fiscal 2013, the Company effected equity contributions of approximately $3.5 million to DCIP, and expects to make additional equity contributions in the future.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P40_S2	DCIP s initial financing, coupled with a second round of financing completed in March 2011 (which consisted of a new $220.0 million term loan facility), substantially covered the cost of conversion to digital projection for our entire circuit.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P40_S3	DCIP funds the cost of conversion to digital projection principally through the collection of virtual print fees from motion picture studios and equipment lease payments from participating exhibitors, including us.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P40_S4	The Company holds a 46.7% economic interest in DCIP as of December 26, 2013 , while continuing to maintain a one-third voting interest along with each of AMC and Cinemark.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P40_S5	Since the Company does not have a controlling financial interest in DCIP or any of its subsidiaries, it accounts for its investment in DCIP under the equity method of accounting.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P41_S0	As of December 26, 2013 , we operated 7,305 screens outfitted with digital projection systems.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P41_S1	Please refer to Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K for further discussion of DCIP.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S0	We also maintain an investment in Open Road Films, a film distribution company jointly owned by us and AMC.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S1	Open Road Films was created to fill a gap in the marketplace created by the major studios big-budget franchise film strategy by marketing smaller budget films in a cost-effective manner which we believe will drive additional patrons to our theatres and generate a return on our capital investment.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S2	Open Road Films distributed seven films during 2013 which generated national box office revenues of approximately $148.0 million , and intends to distribute approximately six to eight films per year.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S3	We believe our investment in Open Road Films will generate incremental value for our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S4	As of December 26, 2013 , we have invested $20.0 million in cash in Open Road Films and may invest an additional $10.0 million in this joint venture.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S5	The carrying value of the Company's investment in Open Road Films as of December 26, 2013 was approximately $(7.1) million .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S6	We believe our investment in Open Road Films will generate incremental value for our stockholders.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P42_S7	Please refer to Note 4 to the consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K for further discussion of Open Road Films.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P43_S0	DISTRIBUTION Domestic movie theatres are the primary initial distribution channel for domestic film releases.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P43_S1	The theatrical success of a film is often the most important factor in establishing its value in other film distribution channels.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P44_S0	Motion pictures are generally made available through several alternative distribution methods after the theatrical release date, including network and syndicated television, cable and satellite television services, in-home video and DVD and pay-per-view services such as video on demand, digital downloads and streaming via the Internet.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P45_S0	A strong opening run at the theatre can help establish a film's success and substantiate the film's revenue potential.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P45_S1	For example, the value of home video, DVD and pay cable distribution agreements frequently depends on the success of a film's theatrical release.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P46_S0	As the primary distribution mechanism for the public's evaluation of films, we believe that domestic theatrical distribution remains the cornerstone of a film's overall financial success.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P46_S1	The development of additional distribution channels has given motion picture producers the ability to generate a greater portion of a film's revenues through channels other than its theatrical release.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P46_S2	Historically, this potential for increased revenue after a film's initial theatrical release has enabled major motion picture studios and some independent producers to increase the budgets for film production and advertising.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P47_S0	We license films on a film-by-film and theatre-by-theatre basis by negotiating directly with film distributors.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P48_S0	Prior to negotiating for a film license, we evaluate the prospects for upcoming films.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P48_S1	Criteria we consider for each film may include cast, producer, director, genre, budget, comparative film performances and various other market conditions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P48_S2	Successful licensing depends greatly upon the exhibitor's knowledge of trends and historical film preferences of the residents in markets served by each theatre, as well as the availability of commercially successful motion pictures.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P48_S3	Films are licensed from film distributors owned by major production companies and from independent film distributors that distribute films for smaller production companies.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P48_S4	Film distributors typically establish geographic licensing zones and allocate each available film to one theatre within that zone.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P49_S0	In licensing zones where we are the sole exhibitor, we obtain film licenses by selecting a film from among those films being offered and negotiating directly with the distributor.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P49_S1	In zones where there is competition, a distributor will allocate films among the exhibitors in the zone.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P49_S2	When films are licensed under the allocation process, a distributor will select an exhibitor for each film who then negotiates film rental terms directly with the distributor.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P50_S0	Film licenses typically specify rental fees or formulas by which rental fees may be calculated.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P51_S0	Under a sliding scale formula, the distributor receives a percentage of the box office receipts using a pre-determined and mutually agreed upon film rental template.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P51_S1	This formula establishes film rental predicated on box office performance and is the predominant formula used by us to calculate film rental fees.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P52_S0	Under the firm term formula, the exhibitor and distributor agree prior to the exhibition of the film on a specified percentage of the box office receipts to be remitted to the distributor.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P52_S1	Lastly, under the review or settlement method, the exhibitor and distributor negotiate a percentage of the box office receipts to be remitted to the distributor upon completion of the theatrical engagement.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P52_S2	These negotiations typically involve the use of historical settlements or past precedent.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P52_S3	The duration of our film licenses are negotiated with our distributors on a case-by-case basis.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P52_S4	The terms of our license agreements depend on performance of each film.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P52_S5	Marketable movies that are expected to have high box office admission revenues will generally have longer license terms than movies with more uncertain performance and popularity.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P53_S0	Many distributors provide quality first-run movies to the motion picture exhibition industry.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P53_S1	For fiscal 2013 , films shown from our ten major film distributors accounted for approximately 94% of our admissions revenues.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P53_S2	Five of the ten major film distributors each accounted for more than 10% of fiscal 2013 admission revenues.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P53_S3	No single film distributor accounted for more than 20% of fiscal 2013 admissions revenues.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P54_S0	We license films from each of the major distributors and believe that our relationships with these distributors are good.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P54_S1	From year to year, the revenues attributable to individual distributors will vary widely depending upon the number and popularity of films that each one distributes.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P54_S2	In addition to box office admissions revenues, we generated approximately 26.9% of our total revenues from concessions sales during fiscal 2013 .
1168696_14_ITEM1_P55_S0	We emphasize prominent and appealing concession stations designed for rapid and efficient service.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P55_S1	We continually seek to increase concessions sales by actively managing concession line congestion, optimizing product mix and through expansion of our concession offerings, introducing special promotions from time to time and offering employee training and incentive programs to up-sell and cross-sell products.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P55_S2	We have favorable concession supply contracts and have developed an efficient concession purchasing and distribution supply chain.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P55_S3	We have historically maintained strong brand relationships and management negotiates directly with these manufacturers for many of our concession items to obtain competitive prices and to ensure adequate supplies.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P56_S0	To continually address consumer trends and customer preferences, we focus on enlarging our menu of food and beverage products.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P56_S1	We have already enhanced our menu to include hot made-to-order meals, customizable coffee, and other specialty products in select theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P56_S2	During fiscal 2013, we offered an expanded menu of food items in 81 theatres and expect to offer these food items in approximately 75-90 additional theatres during fiscal 2014.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P56_S3	In addition, as of December 26, 2013 , we have successfully launched seven Cinebarre locations which offer patrons the convenience of a variety of lunch and dinner menu options, including beer and wine, at the customer's seat before and during the featured film.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P56_S4	We believe that the enhancement of our food and beverage offerings has had a positive effect on our operating results and we expect to continue to invest in such food and beverage offerings in our theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P57_S0	The motion picture exhibition industry is highly competitive.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P57_S1	Motion picture exhibitors generally compete on the basis of the following competitive factors:
1168696_14_ITEM1_P58_S0	ability and willingness to promote the films that are showing.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P58_S1	We have several hundred competitors nationwide, which vary substantially in size, from small independent exhibitors to large national chains such as AMC and Cinemark.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P58_S2	As a result, our theatres are subject to varying degrees of competition in the regions in which they operate.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P59_S0	or screens in areas in which we operate, which may result in increased competition and excess capacity in those areas.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P59_S1	If this occurs, it may have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P59_S2	As the largest motion picture exhibitor, however, we believe that we will be able to generate economies of scale and operating efficiencies that will give us a competitive advantage over many of our competitors.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P59_S3	We also compete with other motion picture distribution channels, including network and syndicated television, in-home video and DVD, cable/satellite and pay-per-view services such as video on demand, digital downloads and streaming via the Internet.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P59_S4	Other technologies could also have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P60_S0	When motion picture distributors license their products to the domestic exhibition industry, they refrain from licensing their motion pictures to these other distribution channels for a period of time, commonly called the theatrical release window.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P60_S1	The theatrical release window has been stable over the past several years.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P60_S2	However, we believe that a material contraction of the theatrical release window could significantly dilute the consumer appeal of the out-of-home motion picture offering.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P60_S3	As a result, we continue to monitor the status of the theatrical release window during our film licensing decisions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P60_S4	In addition, we compete for the public's leisure time and disposable income with other forms of entertainment, including sporting events, concerts, live theatre and restaurants.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S0	MARKETING AND ADVERTISING Currently, film distributors organize and finance multimedia advertising campaigns for major film releases.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S1	To market our theatres, we utilize Internet, mobile and social media, print and multimedia advertising to inform our patrons of film selections and show times.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S2	In many of our markets, we employ special interactive marketing programs for specific films and concessions items.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S3	Our frequent moviegoer loyalty program, Regal Crown Club , is designed to actively engage our core customers and is the largest loyalty program in our industry.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S4	Regal Crown Club members are eligible for specified awards, such as concession items, based on purchases made at our theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S5	Through the Regal Crown Club , we seek to enhance the customer experience and increase frequency of purchases to generate additional revenue.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S6	As of December 26, 2013 , we had over nine million active members in the Regal Crown Club , and these members accounted for approximately $921 million of the Company's box office and concession revenues during fiscal 2013.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P61_S7	In addition, we seek to develop patron loyalty through a number of other marketing programs such as summer children's film series, cross-promotional ticket redemptions and promotions within local communities.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P62_S0	During 2012, we launched a mobile ticketing application designed to give customers quick access to box office information via their Apple iPhone or Android phone.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P62_S1	The application provides customers the ability to find films, movie information, showtimes and special offers from Regal and purchase tickets for local theatres, thereby expediting the admissions process.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P62_S2	Additionally, the application helps customers stay up-to-date on the latest coupons and Regal Crown Club loyalty program promotions.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P62_S3	This mobile application has been downloaded approximately 1.8 million times since its launch.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P63_S0	Information Technology ("IT") is focused on the customer experience and supporting the efficient operation of our theatres, the management of our business and other revenue-generating opportunities.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P63_S1	The revenue streams generated by attendance and concession sales are fully supported by information systems to monitor cash flow and to detect fraud and inventory shrinkage.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S0	We have implemented software and hardware solutions which provide for enhanced capabilities and efficiency within our theatre operations.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S1	These solutions have enabled us to sell gift cards at various major retailers, grocery and warehouse stores and to redeem those gift cards at our theatre box offices and concession stands.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S2	We continue to expand our ability to sell tickets remotely by using our Internet ticketing partner, Fandango.com, and by offering self-service alternatives, such as ticketing kiosks, print-at-home ticketing, and mobile ticketing.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S3	Our Apple iPhone or Android phone application provides customers the ability to find films, movie information, showtimes, special offers from Regal and purchase tickets for local theatres, thereby expediting the admissions process.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S4	We continue to strategically pursue technologies to improve services to our patrons and provide information to our management, allowing them to operate our theatres efficiently.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S5	In addition, our scheduling systems support the coordination needed to properly allocate our auditoriums between film showings and meetings and events, while also ensuring that movie audiences view the intended advertising and that revenue is allocated to the appropriate business function.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S6	The scheduling systems also provide information electronically and automatically to the media outlets, including newspapers and various online media outlets to drive attendance to our theatres.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S7	The sales and attendance information collected by the theatre systems is used directly for film booking and settlement as well as being the primary source of data for our financial systems.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P64_S8	Our revenues are usually seasonal, coinciding with the timing of releases of motion pictures by the major distributors.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P65_S0	Generally, motion picture studios release the most marketable motion pictures during the summer and the holiday season.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P65_S1	The unexpected emergence of a hit film during other periods can alter the traditional trend.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P66_S0	next fiscal quarter or any other fiscal quarter.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P66_S1	The seasonality of motion picture exhibition, however, has become less pronounced as motion picture studios are releasing motion pictures somewhat more evenly throughout the year.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P67_S0	As of December 26, 2013 , we employed approximately 24,201 persons.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P67_S1	The Company considers its employee relations to be good.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P68_S0	EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT Shown below are the names, ages as of December 26, 2013 , and current positions of our executive officers.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P68_S1	There are no family relationships between any of the persons listed below, or between any of such persons and any of the directors of the Company or any persons nominated or chosen by the Company to become a director or executive officer of the Company.

1168696_14_ITEM1_P69_S1	Prior thereto, Ms. Miles served as our Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer from March 2002 to June 2009.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P69_S2	Additionally, Ms. Miles has served as the Chief Executive Officer of Regal Cinemas, Inc. since June 2009.

1168696_14_ITEM1_P70_S1	Prior thereto, Ms. Miles served as Senior Vice President of Finance from April 1999, when she joined Regal Cinemas, Inc.

1168696_14_ITEM1_P70_S3	From 1989 to 1998, she was with PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP.

1168696_14_ITEM1_P72_S3	Mr. Brandow has served as the Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Regal Cinemas, Inc. since July 2001, and prior to that time he served as Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Regal Cinemas, Inc. since February 2000.
1168696_14_ITEM1_P72_S4	Prior thereto, Mr. Brandow served as Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary from February 1999 when he joined Regal Cinemas, Inc.
